content.title: PEEP Optimization
content.summary: Positive End-Expiratory Pressure (PEEP) maintains alveolar recruitment and prevents collapse at end-expiration. Optimization balances recruitment benefits against overdistension, hemodynamic compromise, and barotrauma. Strategies include ARDSNet PEEP/FiO2 tables, best compliance titration, driving pressure minimization, and esophageal pressure-guided PEEP.
key_points: ARDSNet PEEP/FiO2 tables: standard approach in ARDS
Higher PEEP may benefit severe ARDS but not mild ARDS
Esophageal balloon: measures transpulmonary pressure for PEEP setting
content.statement: PEEP optimization aims to maximize alveolar recruitment while minimizing overdistension and hemodynamic effects, using standardized tables or individualized approaches based on compliance, driving pressure, or transpulmonary pressure measurement.

explanation.intuition: PEEP acts like a doorstop keeping alveoli open at the end of each breath. Too little PEEP and alveoli collapse (atelectrauma); too much and healthy alveoli are overinflated (overdistension). Finding the 'Goldilocks' PEEP keeps most alveoli open with minimal overdistension.
explanation.key_insight: Driving pressure (Pplat - PEEP) may be the most important parameter. Optimizing PEEP to minimize driving pressure (maximize compliance) individualizes PEEP to patient's lung mechanics.
explanation.technical_details: ARDSNet uses low PEEP/FiO2 and high PEEP/FiO2 tables (no mortality difference in most studies). EPVent-2 used esophageal pressure to titrate PEEP to transpulmonary pressure >0 - no mortality benefit. Decremental PEEP titration after recruitment maneuver is an alternative approach.

definitions_glossary.PEEP: Positive end-expiratory pressure maintained between breaths
definitions_glossary.recruitment: Opening collapsed alveoli through positive pressure
definitions_glossary.atelectrauma: Lung injury from repetitive opening/closing of alveoli
definitions_glossary.driving_pressure: Plateau pressure minus PEEP; force distending the lung
definitions_glossary.compliance: Change in volume per unit pressure; reflects lung stiffness
definitions_glossary.esophageal_pressure: Surrogate for pleural pressure using esophageal balloon
definitions_glossary.barotrauma: Lung injury from high pressures (pneumothorax, pneumomediastinum)
definitions_glossary.recruitment_maneuver: Transient high PEEP to open collapsed lung units
definitions_glossary.auto_PEEP: Intrinsic PEEP from incomplete exhalation (air trapping)
definitions_glossary.best_PEEP: PEEP level optimizing recruitment vs overdistension

pathophysiology.mechanism: PEEP maintains positive pressure at end-expiration → keeps alveoli open → improves V/Q matching → improves oxygenation
pathophysiology.balance: Must avoid overdistension (high Pplat) and hemodynamic compromise (decreased venous return)

ARDSNet_tables.approach: Match PEEP to FiO2 using low or high PEEP tables
ARDSNet_tables.evidence: No mortality difference between high and low PEEP in unselected ARDS

driving_pressure_guided.description: Set PEEP to minimize driving pressure
driving_pressure_guided.approach: Increase PEEP, measure Pplat; optimal PEEP when driving pressure lowest
driving_pressure_guided.evidence: Lower driving pressure associated with survival in retrospective analyses

compliance_guided.description: Incremental or decremental PEEP titration to find best compliance
compliance_guided.approach: After recruitment, decrease PEEP and find compliance peak
compliance_guided.evidence: Physiologically sound but no mortality trial data

esophageal_pressure_guided.description: Measure transpulmonary pressure to set PEEP
esophageal_pressure_guided.approach: Titrate PEEP to transpulmonary PEEP >0 at end-expiration
esophageal_pressure_guided.evidence: EPVent-2 showed improved oxygenation but not mortality

practical_considerations.starting_PEEP: 5-8 cmH2O for most patients; higher in ARDS
practical_considerations.hemodynamic_effects: May decrease preload/CO - monitor BP; may need fluids

definition.@value: Strategies to optimize positive end-expiratory pressure to maximize alveolar recruitment while minimizing overdistension and hemodynamic compromise

learning_objectives: Explain the physiological rationale for PEEP
Recognize signs of inappropriate PEEP (overdistension vs derecruitment)
clinical_pearls: Driving pressure <15 cmH2O is associated with better outcomes
SpO2 92-96% is adequate - don't chase 100% with excessive PEEP/FiO2
If BP drops with PEEP increase, may indicate hypovolemia or RV strain
Auto-PEEP (intrinsic PEEP) must be measured to assess total PEEP

citations.authors: Amato MB, Meade MO, Slutsky AS, et al.
citations.title: Driving pressure and survival in the acute respiratory distress syndrome

evidence.confidence_rationale: Driving pressure analysis and PEEP trials
